SUNS LOSE FLEXIBILITY IN DEAL  
 RULES IMPROVE ODDS OF KEEPING MCDYESS 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By BOB YOUNG  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   The Suns still may raid the Chicago Bulls, but it probably isn't
going to be for forward Scottie Pippen.

   Even Minnesota forward Tom Gugliotta looks like a long shot
based on the new collective bargaining agreement hammered out
between the NBA and its players on Wednesday.

   After positioning themselves for the past two years to have the
flexibility to go after a major free agent, or maybe even two, the
Suns are likely to find themselves severely limited by the new
deal.

   Instead of Pippen, the Suns may only have enough money available
under the new rules to sign a player such as Chicago center Luc
Longley.

   But the agreement also appears to give the Suns a big advantage
in their efforts to keep forward Antonio McDyess from defecting to
Houston.

   ``Anytime you talk about Jerry and Bryan Colangelo, you have to
think somehow, some way, they're going to put a team out there that
can compete for the championship,'' Suns guard Jason Kidd said of
the Suns president and the general manager.

   Details of the agreement are still sketchy, and Suns officials
would not comment.

   But based on the particulars of the owners' last proposal and
information gleaned from NBA sources, the Suns and other clubs that
hoped to free up considerable salary cap space for free agents will
have to take another look at their blueprints.

   The Suns may be better off keeping much of last season's team,
plugging in a good big man such as Longley, adding a second-tier
free agent with a new salary cap exception that has been added in
the new deal, and then filling out the roster with young,
developing players.

   The Suns have five players under contract _ Danny Manning, Jason
Kidd, Mark Bryant, Martin Muursepp and Bubba Wells. Muursepp and
Wells were part of the Steve Nash deal with Dallas. They also have
a first-round draft pick, forward Pat Garrity, and a
second-rounder, guard Toby Bailey, from trades. Bailey doesn't
count against the salary cap as a second-round pick.

   The team then has several free agents that it must re-sign or
renounce, including three key players _ McDyess, Rex Chapman and
Clifford Robinson.

   That's where it really gets tricky. All but Robinson, if not
renounced, count against the cap at 200 percent of their salaries
last season instead of 150 percent, as under the previous
agreement.

   As an example, McDyess would have counted $4.3 million against
the cap under the old rules. He now counts about $5.75 million
unless he signs with another team.

   The Larry Bird exception, although modified, still exists, and
under the new rules, the Suns are in a good position to keep
McDyess. As a Bird free agent, he can get a seven-year deal from
the Suns.

   He can get only a six-year deal from Houston or any other team.
The Suns can give him 12.5 percent annual increases from a base
salary of $9 million under the new rules. Other teams can give him
only 10 percent increases.

   Another salary cap charge that has been added is for players
whose rights are renounced. Assuming the Suns kept their five
contract players and their key free agents, and sign Garrity, they
would have three roster spots remaining.

   If they chose to renounce their remaining free agents _ such as
Kevin Johnson, John ``Hot Rod'' Williams, Marko Milic, Horacio
Llamas, Loren Meyer and George McCloud _ the Suns still would be
charged $300,000 against the cap for each remaining open roster
spot _ a $900,000 cap charge.

   Also, the projected number for this season's salary cap was
supposed to be $31 million. According to reports, the new number
actually will be $30 million.

   Figuring the five Suns under contract, the free agents the club
will try to re-sign, plus the charge for the other roster spots,
about $25 million of that $30 million would be eaten up.

   Pippen probably wouldn't come to Phoenix for a contract that
starts at $5 million.

   The Colangelos will have some tough decisions, especially on
Robinson. If the club keeps him, it would eat up more cap space.

   Re-signing McDyess is likely to be the top priority, but if he
signs elsewhere, it would more than double the available cap space,
and the Suns likely would go after one of the other high-profile
players.

   The new agreement includes a new ``median'' salary exception,
which starts at $1.75 million and eventually will be worth the
league average salary.

   With almost 200 free agents available, there will be some
bargains. A player such as the Lakers' Rick Fox or Miami's Brent
Barry might slip through the cracks, as Robinson did before last
season.

   Keep in mind, too, that the rest of the league is working under
the same restrictions the Suns now face, and the Phoenix franchise
has a history of being creative in these situations.

   ``I'm sure Bryan has his calculator out, and he's gone through
all the scenarios,'' Kidd said.
